journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: Detection and material identification of loose particles inside the aerospace power supply via stochastic resonance and LVQ network

article-meta.aff: 1School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, P. R. China
2Army Aviation Institute of PLA, Beijing, P. R. China

author-notes.corresp: Long Zhang, School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Harbin Institute of Technology, 150001, Harbin, P. R. China Email: zhanglonghit@gmail.com

abstract.p: The detection of loose particles inside an aerospace power supply is important to improve the reliability of the whole space system. This paper investigates the detection and material identification of loose particles within an aerospace power supply based on the particle impact noise detection (PIND) test. A stochastic resonance algorithm is employed to detect the presence of tiny particles. A learning vector quantization (LVQ)-based material identification method is proposed. Finally, experiments are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique. Experimental results show that the accuracies of particle detection and material identification are above 90% and 80%, respectively, which meets end-user requirements.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An aerospace power supply is widely used to supply power for the aerospace system. Loose particles within it, such as granular tin, copper shot, iron filings and wire skin, can cause catastrophic failures. For example, their moving into bared bond wires could short out the parts for a brief time during usage. Therefore, aerospace power supplies must be screened for loose particles. So far, the manufacturers of aerospace power supplies mainly rely on the artificial detection of loose particles, as there is no relative automatic method or device, so this paper aims to develop an automatic method for detecting particles in the aerospace power supplies referring to the particle impact noise detection (PIND) test.

The PIND test is a typical method for detecting the presence of loose particles inside the electromagnetic relay, and its typical structure is shown in Figure 1 (Gao et al., 2007; Zhang et al., 2008). Its process is as follows:

caption.p: Typical structure of particle impact noise detection (PIND) test system.

list-item.p: The component under test is attached to an acoustic sensor mounted on the top of a vibration shaker.
The shaker induces a series of mechanical shocks and vibrations to free loose particles clinging to the interior of the component.
An acoustic wave is generated from the resulting impacts between the freed particles and the component interior.
The above wave is converted into an electrical signal by the acoustic sensor.

The electrical signal is processed by the electronic circuit into two kinds of signals – one kind is an audio signal to drive a speaker and the other kind is a visible waveform shown in an oscilloscope.
The operator can determine the presence of the loose particles by both the audio and visual signals.

sec.p: The small shaker in the PIND test is incapable of shaking the aerospace power supplies, which have large volumes and heavy weights. Hence, a large turntable with higher drive power rather than the shaker is used to free particles. Additionally, the PIND test is a semi-automatic method because the operator draws on the experimental conclusion either by watching the waveform or by listening to the audio signal, where the operator’s fatigue, neglect and lack of experience could easily lead to the wrong conclusions. Although the PIND test could detect the existence of large particles effectively, the drawbacks of this method are its low accuracy for the detection of tiny particles and its inability to provide information about the particle materials. The information is of great importance to manufacturers for determining the sources of loose particles. To address the above issues, the particle signal is collected by a data acquisition card and analysed by the computer software in this paper. The main structure of the novel particle detection system for the aerospace power supply is shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Structure of the particle detection system for the aerospace power supply.

sec.p: The collected acoustic signal generated by the PIND test consists of background noise and loose particle signal if there exist loose particles in the component under test. Thus, the key point for particle detection is how to extract a useful particle signal from noise precisely, especially in the case of weak particle signal with heavy noise, generated by tiny particles. A detection method for loose particles inside electromagnetic relays has been studied (Gao et al., 2007; Zhang et al, 1997). The wavelet transform was employed to remove the background noise and then a threshold method was used to detect the presence of particles from the de-noised signal. Although the traditional method could detect the existence of large particles, it has low accuracy for tiny particle detection, as the useful frequency information of the particle signal, overlapping with the noise, is partly eliminated during the de-noising process. To address this issue, a detection method for tiny particles based on stochastic resonance is proposed in this paper. The new method makes good use of background noise instead of de-noising it (Asdi and Tewfik, 1995; Chen et al., 2008; Harmer et al., 2002; Leng, 2004). In addition, it is difficult and complex for material identification because of the complexity that even the same material presents different time and frequency domain characteristics with respect to different shapes, sizes and weights. The particles inside relays are classified by a linear method (Wang et al., 2007); a drawback of this method is its low accuracy for material identification. To solve this problem, this paper presents a novel material identification method by employing both the wavelet packet transform to extract the eigenvectors of different material particles and neural networks to classify the material.

sec.title: Characteristics of the particle signal andsystem noise
sec.p: The acoustic signal generated by impacts created by loose particles inside the cavities of aerospace power supplies consists of the useful particle signal and system noise. The particle signal is a series of oscillation attenuation pulses and its frequency ranges from 30 to 140 kHz, especially distributing around 80 kHz of which is determined by the inherent frequency characteristic of the acoustic sensor. The system noise consists of power frequency interference, power line interference and thermal noise of the electrical circuit. Through the analysis of frequency domain, it can be concluded that power frequency interference has a low amplitude with a fixed frequency, whereas the power line interference and thermal noise are both wideband random noise. The signals of large particles and tiny particles are shown in Figures 3 and 4, respectively, whereas the system noise is shown in Figure 5.

sec.title: Stochastic resonance detection algorithm
sec.p: Generally, when noise is added to a system, the output deteriorates in quality. However, the phenomenon of the stochastic resonance is that, in some non-linear systems with a weak low-frequency input signal, adding the right amount of the system noise could enhance the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of system output. This is the synergy of the system noise, the weak signal and the non-linear system. A typical non-linear bi-stable stochastic resonance model is given by (Chen et al., 2008; Harmer et al., 2002):

where x is the system output, a and b are structure parameters of the non-linear system, s(t) is the input signal, N(t) is Gaussian white noise and meets the conditions of zero mean given by E[N(t)]=0 and the autocorrelation function given by E[N(t)N(t+τ)]=2Dδ(t−τ), where D is the noise intensity. This essentially describes the over-damped motion of a mass point driven by both external forces and noise in a double potential well.
When system noise and input signal are absent (s(t)=0, N(t)=0), the potential function is

The barrier height of the bi-stable system is ΔV=a2/4b, and its two steady state points are xm=±a/b, where the potential function reaches the minimum. For example, in the case of a=1 and b=1, the potential well graph of the bi-stable system is shown in Figure 6.

caption.p: Potential well graph of bi-stable system.

sec.p: On the other hand, when the input periodic signal and system noise are present, the noise could enhance the output of the non-linear bi-stable system. If the amplitude of the input signal is lower than the critical value Ac=4a3/27b, the mass point is likely to switch between the two potential wells, whose switching frequency is synchronous with that of the weak periodic signal, and therefore the state transition enhances the SNR of the output signal. According to adiabatic approximation, the SNR of the output signal is given by (Chen et al., 2008):

sec.title: Numerical simulation of stochastic resonance algorithm
sec.p: A numerical iterative algorithm is given to solve the non-linear Equation (1) based on the Runge–Kutta algorithm (Yang and Hu, 2003),
Here, h=1/fs is the step size, fs is the sampling rate, snn is the nth signal sampling point of the weak periodic signal with system noise and x is the system output.
To void iteration divergence, the numerical simulation conditions of the stochastic resonance of the bi-stable system are given by

sec.title: Conditions of stochastic resonance
sec.p: Stochastic resonance occurs if both the amplitude and frequency of the weak input signal coupled with the intensity of system noise are far less than 1 according to adiabatic theory (Leng, 2004). However, the frequency of the particle signal is as high as 80 kHz, which could not be directly used as the input signal. To meet the requirements of stochastic resonance, the sub-sample method is used to reduce the high frequency of the particle signal to the low-frequency signal and the sub-sample rate is 50 times than that of the particle signal (Guo et al. 2006; Leng and Wang, 2003; Leng et al., 2004).
To produce stochastic resonance, the selection of system parameters is also a key step. The process is as follows: the expression (1) with the white noise is normalized to be (Leng, 2004):

Here, y=x/D,b¯=bD,s¯=s/D, N0(t) is the normalized Gaussian white noise with the intensity of 1. The height of the potential well in the normalized non-linear bi-stable system becomes ΔV=a2/4b¯=a2/4bD. Hence, adjusting either a and D, or a and b could generate stochastic resonance. If a and D are adjusted, the noise intensity needs to be tuned accordingly, but the noise intensity could not be tuned easily as practical random noise could not be precisely quantized, whereas if a and b are adjusted and D is not changed, the corresponding height change of the potential well could directly lead to stochastic resonance. So far, there is no relevant systematic theory guiding the adjusting or selection of a and b. The numerical simulation is used to select a and b, and then verified by experiments. To achieve highest detection precision, numerical simulation and verification are repeated until system parameters become optimal.

sec.title: Tiny particle detection based on stochastic resonance algorithm
sec.p: The selection of the parameters of a and b by simulation for maximum enhancement of stochastic resonance is explained here. The estimated system noise shown in Figure 7 is taken as the only input of the non-linear bi-stable system. The tiny particle signal shown in Figure 8 is then added into the system noise, located between 0.4 s and 0.6 s as shown in Figure 9. Thereafter, the values of a and b are adjusted so that the output of the non-linear system could only generate the state transition on the condition of the simultaneous existence of the tiny particle signal and system noise.

caption.p: Weak periodic signal of tiny particle.

sec.p: Through simulation, the structural parameters of the bi-stable system a=2, b=20 000 are obtained and its two steady state points are xm=±a/b=±0.01. Figure 10 shows the output of stochastic resonance system, where the system generates state transition at the location, indicating existence of the tiny particles. Practical tests show that the estimated parameters meet user requirements and one of the results is shown in Figure 11.

caption.p: Stochastic resonance output of practical tiny particle signal.

sec.title: Material identification of particles
sec.p: The manufactory survey shows that the typical loose particles within the aerospace power supply mainly include granular tin, copper shot, iron filings and wire skin. The material identification is a pattern classification problem. The material information is of great importance to manufacturers for determining sources of loose particles. The performance of classification is determined by the accuracy of both the eigenvectors extracted from the collected data set and the classifiers mapping eigenvectors to decision space (Bianchi et al., 2000; Gounmas and Zervakis, 2002; Li et al., 2005). In this paper, wavelet packet transform is employed to extract eigenvectors from the non-stationary particle signal and the learning vector quantization (LVQ) neural network is used as a non-linear classifier for material identification.

sec.title: Eigenvector extraction
sec.p: Both time-domain and frequency-domain methods are extensively used for eigenvector extraction. The linear prediction coding, a typical time-domain method, analysing the correlation of sampling data, was adopted to classify the signal of loose particles within relays (Wang et al., 2007) and two drawbacks were identical. Firstly, it has low accuracy for material identification. Furthermore, even the same material loose particles present different time-domain characteristics with regard to different shapes, sizes and weights. Fourier power spectrum analysis and wavelet packet transforms are typical frequency-domain methods. Power spectrums of four kinds of particles, extracted by Fourier power spectrum analysis, are shown in Figures 12–15. It can be concluded that energy distribution of different material particles is different. However, the Fourier method is not as sensitive as wavelet packet transforms for a non-stationary signal. Wavelet packet transform not only deals with the low-frequency scale factors, but also processes high-frequency wavelet coefficients subspace (Deng and Ling, 1999; Carnero and Drygajlo, 1999; Linkens et al., 2000; Philippe et al., 1999), suitable for processing a particle signal with wide energy distribution. To obtain more material information about the particle signal, wavelet packet transform instead of Fourier transform is employed to extract eigenvectors in this paper.

The loose particle signal x(N) is decomposed by wavelet packets into m layers and 2m wavelet tree nodes subspace (Eren and Devaney, 2004; Sadeghian et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2005). In this paper, energy distribution vector e is defined by
Here, WPTi is the coefficient of wavelet decomposition. It can be concluded that e is a scalar with characters as follows.

Two key issues for eigenvector extraction using wavelet packet decomposition are the determination of the layer number of the wavelet packet and the selection of the wavelet function. By definition, high dimensions of the energy distribution vector lead to the high-frequency information about the particle material. Experimental results show that the performance of the three-layer wavelet packet decomposition is similar to that of more than three layers. To save computational overheads in wavelet packet decomposition, three-layer wavelet packet decomposition is used and its energy distribution vector is in eight dimensions. For the wavelet function, a DB4 wavelet is employed because of its superiority over other wavelet functions such as Symlet and Haar through experimental analysis, and therefore is used. The energy distribution vectors of four typical different material particles are shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Energy distribution vectors of typical particles

sec.title: Material identification using learning vector quantization network
sec.p: The relationship between eigenvectors and the material type is non-linear. An LVQ neural network could deal with complex non-linear models without previously providing decision functions. It has excellent performance on phonemic classification tasks and is characterized as self-organizing, noise immunity and generalization ability.

An LVQ network consists of an input layer, a hidden layer and an output layer, as shown in Figure 16. The hidden layer is an unsupervised self-organizing map (SOM). The output layer is a supervised linear layer classifying the derived classes into target classes (Fung et al., 1997; Lyons and Lewis, 2000; Shin et al., 2000; Xu, 2008).

caption.p: Structure of learning vector quantization (LVQ) network. SOM, self-organizing map.

sec.p: The input and output variables, the number of the hidden layer and structural parameters of the LVQ network are identified as follows:

list-item.p: A set of six representative training samples are provided for each kind of particles, of which three samples are noise-free samples and the others are added with 5% noise. The input variables of the LVQ network are the energy distribution vectors extracted from the above samples by wavelet packet decomposition, whereas the expected outputs are 1, 2, 3 and 4, representing copper, iron, tin and wire skin, respectively.

The number of neurons in the hidden layer is determined by the minimal training and testing errors, and experimental results show that the LVQ network with 200 neurons has good generalization ability.

The training process where the structural parameters are identified is shown in Figure 17. It can be seen that the network converges when the number of the iterations is less than 300, where the training error reduces within the setting error.
If the test results are not satisfactory, the energy distribution vectors are reselected and steps (1) to (3) are then repeated until the results are optimal.

caption.p: Training result of learning vector quantization (LVQ) network.

sec.p: The training and test processes for the LVQ network are implemented using the Matlab neural network toolbox, whereas the other functions such as sampling, analysis, detection algorithm and human machine interface are coded by the visual C++ program. The two programs are finally combined together by calling Matlab functions in the visual C++.

sec.title: The structure of the automatic detection system
sec.p: The automatic detection system is designed to detect the presence of loose particles and identify their material types. It is composed of a turntable and a console. The turntable is used to excite the loose particles within the aerospace power supply. The console is employed to sample and analyse the acoustic signals generated by impacts created by loose particles, and it consists of a high sensitivity acoustic sensor, a signal processing circuit, a data acquisition card and a computer software. The collected data is transmitted to the computer by PCI bus and then analysed by the computer software for particle detection and material classification. The physical system is shown in Figure 18.

sec.title: Experimental set-up and result analysis
sec.p: The experimental set-up is used manually to embed different loose particles into different aerospace power supplies, set-up turntable speed and test time. More specifically, the embedded particles include four kinds of material particles, of which each kind has a different weight ranging from 0.5 to 2.5 mg increased approximately by 0.1 mg, coupled with four types of shapes including square, triangle, circle and polygon. So there are 336 test samples, along with extra 20 samples without any particles. The recoverable experimental results of particle detection and material identification are shown in Tables 2 and 3, respectively.

The accuracies of particle detection and material classification are above 90% and 80%, respectively. Error detection is mainly caused by the failure that loose particles adhere to the cavity of the aerospace power supply and are not freed, whereas error classification is related to the large discrepancy in energy distribution vectors of the same material particles.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the problem of detection and material identification of loose particles inside aerospace power supplies is studied and some valuable conclusions are drawn as follows:

list-item.p: The particle detection method based on a stochastic resonance algorithm is presented to detect the presence of loose particles. This method enhances the output signal-to-noise ratio of a non-linear bi-stable system whose parameters are determined by simulation, optimization and experimental verification. The performance of this particle detection method shows its superiority over the de-noising method used in the literature.

An LVQ-based material identification method of loose particles is proposed. According to characteristics of particle signals, energy distribution vectors in wavelet domain are taken as eigenvectors of particle material, and an LVQ network is used as the non-linear classifier.

An automatic detection system is developed for the experimental verification. Experimental results show that the accuracies of particle detection and material identification are above 90% and 80%, respectively, which meets end-user requirements.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
